greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Table T(n,k) (listed antidiagonalwise in order T(0,0), T(1,0), T(0,1), T(2,0), T(1,1), ...) giving the number of rooted plane binary trees of size n and "contracted height" k.
comment: The height of binary trees is computed here in the same way as in A073345, except that whenever a complete binary tree of (2^k)-1 nodes with all its leaves at the same level, i.e., one of the following trees:
is encountered as a terminating subtree, it is regarded just a variant of . (an empty tree, a single leaf) and contributes nothing to the height of the tree.
link: H. Bottomley and A. Karttunen, Notes concerning diagonals of the square arrays A073345 and A073346.
formula: (See the Maple code below. Note that here we use the same convolution recurrence as with A073345, but only the initial conditions for the first two rows (k=0 and k=1) are different. Is there a nicer formula?)
example: The top-left corner of this square array:
xref: Variant: A073345. The first row: A036987. Column sums: A000108. Diagonals: T(n, n) = A000007(n), T(n+1, n) = A000079(n), T(n+2, n) = A058922(n), T(n+3, n) = A074092(n) - [see the attached notes.].
A073430 gives the upper triangular region of this array. Used to compute A073431. Entries on row k are all divisible by 2^k, thus dividing them out yields the array/triangle A074079/A074080.
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Jul 31 2002
